channel.title: BBC News

item.title: First leukaemia patient to receive pioneering treatment on NHS says it is 'very sci-fi'
item.description: Oscar Murphy has an aggressive form of the blood cancer and is the first to get CAR-T therapy in the UK.

item.title: Safe spaces needed for drug-addicted children, say grieving mums
item.description: More children in England are in drug and alcohol treatment, but families say many cannot get help.

item.title: Lib Dems set out plan to end 12-hour A&E waits
item.description: Party leader Ed Davey calls for £1.5bn to be spent on ending a "deadly corridor crisis" in the NHS.

item.title: I spent months trying to find out if boosting my gut health could help me age better
item.description: Health editor Hugh Pym revamped his diet after a test suggested his gut health appeared to look five years older than he was

item.title: Revolutionary eye injection saved my sight, says first-ever patient
item.description: Nicki's eye had collapsed in on itself, but a new gel injection method has saved her vision.

item.title: Critical incidents declared at two hospital trusts
item.description: NHS bosses are urging people to only come to A&E if it is an emergency.

item.title: Boy with flu spent three weeks in intensive care
item.description: His family is urging other parents to ensure their children are vaccinated against the virus.

item.title: Why the NHS still wastes billions on patients who don't need to be in hospital
item.description: The delayed discharge challenge throws up deeper questions about the care system, co-ordination - and whether some patients are over-treated

item.title: Eye surgeon's advice after his own sight-saving op
item.description: Dr Amir Hamid said his sight was saved by quick treatment when he had symptoms of a detached retina.

item.title: People who come off slimming jabs regain weight four times faster than dieters
item.description: Overweight people shed large amounts on jabs but gain 0.8 kg a month on average once off them, study shows.

item.title: Flu on the rise again after Christmas mixing, says NHS
item.description: Cases up after two weeks of decline, as hospitals report rise in slips and falls because of cold snap.

item.title: Doctors strike called off as union backs latest pay deal
item.description: Medics had been set to go on the first national walkout staged by NHS workers on Tuesday in a dispute over pay.

item.title: Long waits for disability benefit claims unacceptable, MPs say
item.description: Some people are waiting more than a year to have their claims processed, the Public Accounts Committee says.

item.title: Three NHS trusts still using fax machines, Streeting confesses
item.description: The health secretary had made it his personal mission to banish the fax machine from the NHS.

item.title: Parents say babies failed by delayed diagnosis like Jesy Nelson's twins
item.description: After Little Mix star Jesy Nelson's revelation that her twins have SMA, parents speak about their children's late diagnoses.

item.title: Junk food TV and online advert ban comes into force
item.description: Soft drinks, chocolate, pizzas and ice creams will be targeted in the UK government's plan.

item.title: Wellbeing 2026: Recovery, JOMO and brain boosting supplements
item.description: Wellness is a multi-trillion pound industry which continues to grow - and this year is less about maxing out, more about recovering well.

item.title: The myth of willpower - and why some people struggle to lose weight more than others
item.description: Thousands of genes that have an influence on weight, say experts - which means weight loss isn't a level playing field

item.title: Chickenpox vaccines for young children start across UK
item.description: For the first time, children will be offered vaccination on the NHS against the common infection which, in rare cases, can be very serious.

item.title: Surgeon who 'stripped naked in cubicle' struck off
item.description: The doctor was working at the Queen Alexandra Hospital in Portsmouth when the incidents happened.

item.title: The debate about whether the NHS should use magic mushrooms to treat depression
item.description: Many clinical trials to test the use of psychedelic medicines for conditions such as depression have been underway since 2022 - with surprising results

item.title: Christmas can be a nightmare for misophonia sufferers like me
item.description: Christmas is a difficult time if you suffer from a reduced tolerance to sounds, but there are ways to make it easier.

item.title: Hospitals warned end-of-life care crisis threatening treatment
item.description: A rising number of patients in hospitals could affect the level of treatment carried out this winter, a group of regional NHS leaders have been told.

item.title: Hospitals working to get patients home for Christmas after five-day doctor strike
item.description: Health experts have warned that the impact of the strike will be felt into the new year "and beyond".

item.title: US regulator approves pill form of Wegovy weight-loss drug
item.description: Wegovy becomes first pill of its kind to be approved, shifting weight-loss drugs beyond injections.

item.title: TikTok removes AI weight loss ads from fake Boots account
item.description: The adverts for prescription-only drugs showed healthcare professionals impersonating the British retailer.

item.title: Weight-loss jabs: What happens when you stop?
item.description: You may have lost the weight you wanted to lose - but now you've stopped the jabs, how easy is it to keep it off?

item.title: Flu: How are hospitals in your area affected?
item.description: Use our interactive tool to explore the latest flu numbers in your area

item.title: What is happening to flu this winter - and should you buy a vaccine?
item.description: Flu has come early this year with a new mutated version of the virus circulating.

item.title: Toddler finally home from hospital for Christmas
item.description: Bertie Melly was in hospital for 18 months after his premature birth in May 2024.

item.title: Is it a cold, 'super flu' or Covid? How to tell the difference
item.description: How to identify whether you have cold, flu or Covid and how to look after yourself.

item.title: Flu wave hits England's busiest A&E - hundreds of patients are arriving a day
item.description: The BBC visits Leicester Royal Infirmary to witness first-hand how it's coping with an early surge in cases of winter bugs.

item.title: What's really going on with flu this winter?
item.description: We've been told we're facing an unprecedented superflu. Is it?

item.title: Has flu peaked? What the figures tell us
item.description: NHS remains on high alert over flu, health bosses say, but there are signs infections are levelling off.

item.title: Private flu vaccine stocks running low as cases rise
item.description: Those eligible for a vaccine can access jabs from the NHS, but experts say that people have turned to pharmacies for convenience.

item.title: Ambulance demand spikes as flu season worsens
item.description: The service says calls increased by 20% in the past week, fuelled by illnesses such as the flu.

item.title: Some schools disrupted amid rise in flu cases
item.description: Flu is on the rise, but ministers say schools should only close in extreme circumstances.

item.title: Flu jabs offered in pub in vaccination drive
item.description: Regular pop-up vaccination clinics are available at The Bevy community pub in Brighton.

item.title: Much of £11bn Covid scheme fraud 'beyond recovery', report says
item.description: The response to the pandemic led to "enormous outlays of public money which exposed it to the risk of fraud and error", a report says.

item.title: Government racks up £100m bill responding to Covid inquiry
item.description: BBC analysis shows cost to taxpayer is 50% higher than thought, with inquiry's own costs at £192m.

item.title: Lockdown could have been avoided - key findings from Covid inquiry
item.description: The long-awaited report is published into how well or badly the government handled the Covid pandemic.

item.title: The Covid Inquiry Podcast
item.description: Baroness Hallett makes her second report into the UK's pandemic response. With Jim Reed.

item.title: The private notes and secret documents that tell the inside story of the UK's Covid response
item.description: The Covid inquiry is set to publish its second set of findings looking in detail at the huge political decisions that had to be made in 2020.

item.title: 'Toxic' No 10 culture harmed Covid response, inquiry finds
item.description: Boris Johnson, Dominic Cummings and Matt Hanock are all criticised for contributing to poor Covid decision-making.

item.title: Covid inquiry hears impact on firms and staff
item.description: Business owners describe breaking into tears as they were forced to lay off staff, while workers feared for their jobs

item.title: UK did 'too little, too late', leading to thousands more Covid deaths - inquiry
item.description: Report on government decision-making says delays cost 23,000 lives in the first wave in England.

item.title: What's in the Covid inquiry report... in 68 seconds
item.description: The report looks at whether lockdowns were timely and reasonable, and what impact rule-breaking at the heart of government had on public confidence.

item.title: What is the UK Covid inquiry and how does it work?
item.description: The inquiry into the government's handling of the pandemic has heard from politicians, civil servants, experts and bereaved families.

item.title: Gove apologises after Covid report alleges 'toxic' culture
item.description: The ex-senior minister apologises for mistakes in the pandemic, but defends some of the previous government's actions.

item.title: Delayed action before 2020 Christmas lockdown 'inexcusable'
item.description: Baroness Hallet says ministers failed to take "decisive action" against an "entirely foreseeable" variant.

item.title: 'Since having Covid my life has completely changed'
item.description: A teenager has told the Covid-19 inquiry she often feels "left out" after missing so much school.

item.title: Boris Johnson left Inquiry in a hurry - he'll be pleased not to come back
item.description: School closures seemed the only option but lockdowns probably went "too far" , former PM tells Covid Inquiry.

item.title: One day of planning went into Covid school closures, inquiry hears
item.description: This part of the inquiry is looking at the impact the pandemic had on children and young people.

item.title: Covid inquiry hears of 'generational slaughter'
item.description: Relatives of care home residents tell the Covid inquiry they will never get over how their loved ones died.

item.title: Hancock ignored call to test all NHS staff, Covid inquiry hears
item.description: Two Nobel prize-winning scientists worried about "asymptomatic transmission" between staff and patients.

item.title: Large UK-wide pandemic preparedness tests planned this year
item.description: The stress test will involve thousands of people to help the UK prepare for potential future threats.

item.title: Families failed by Covid jabs tell inquiry of pain
item.description: They said there was no support after the death and harm suffered by their loved ones.

item.title: NHS hours from PPE running out in Covid - Hancock
item.description: Former health secretary tells inquiry some healthcare settings did run out - "and it was awful".

item.title: How I proved hair loss and dizziness aren't just symptoms of 'being a mum'
item.description: Iron deficiency is a relatively common problem, especially in women. Here's how to spot the symptoms.

item.title: Prostate cancer screening: What you need to know
item.description: Everything you need to know about the decision on who should be screened for prostate cancer.

item.title: Sugar tax extended to milk-based drinks: What you need to know
item.description: Milkshakes and lattes to be included in UK sugar tax scheme for the first time.

item.title: How do cold weather health alerts work?
item.description: The weather alert service warns the public when high or low temperatures could damage their health.

item.title: NHS tracker - are hospital waiting times improving near you?
item.description: Use our interactive tracker to see if treatment waits are getting better at your local hospital.

item.title: Ever feel the need to switch off? Your vagus nerve might hold the key
item.description: You might not have heard of it, but can training your vagus nerve give you a moment or two of peace?

item.title: 'A predator in your home': Mothers say chatbots encouraged their sons to kill themselves
item.description: In her first UK interview Megan Garcia speaks to Laura Kuenssberg about the death of her teenage son.

item.title: You can now book online to see your GP. But is it any easier to get an appointment?
item.description: A month since GPs in England started offering online appointment bookings, patients recount their experiences.

item.title: ADHD services shutting door to new NHS patients as demand soars, BBC finds
item.description: A BBC investigation finds that a host of areas in England are closing waiting lists and others are rationing care.

item.title: DNA pioneer James Watson dies at 97
item.description: Watson co-discover the double-helix structure of DNA, but his reputation was later damaged by his comments on race and sex.

item.title: I wanted ChatGPT to help me. So why did it advise me how to kill myself?
item.description: ChatGPT wrote a woman a suicide note and another AI chatbot role-played sexual acts with children, BBC finds.

item.title: Illegal teeth-whitening industry exposed by BBC
item.description: A BBC investigation finds kits on sale containing more than 500 times the legal limit of bleach.

item.title: What is Mpox and why are cases rising in Europe?
item.description: UK health officials are encouraging gay, bisexual and other men who have sex with men to be vaccinated.

item.title: Magnesium: Can this 'miracle mineral' really help us sleep?
item.description: The global market in this supplement is worth almost £3bn - a figure set to nearly double over the next decade.

item.title: 'I have a sweating problem': What Alan Carr's Traitors admission tells us about how social taboos changed
item.description: Let's talk about sweat... From contestants on The Celebrity Traitors and scores of celebrities openly discussing it, to the trend of professionals using saunas for business meetings

item.title: 'Getting financial help through my GP has improved my health'
item.description: How linked are financial worries and health? GPs in London are trialling a financial support scheme.

item.title: What are the symptoms of prostate cancer and what should you check for?
item.description: One in eight men will be diagnosed with prostate cancer in their lifetime.

item.title: A facelift at 28? Why young people are turning to plastic surgery
item.description: Gone are the days when facelifts were for the ageing wealthy. Now younger people are going under the knife.

item.title: Your nose gets colder when you're stressed. These thermal images show the change
item.description: Psychologists subjected a BBC reporter to a carefully designed thermal camera stress test.

item.title: My eating disorder made me good at lying, says Victoria Beckham
item.description: The former Spice Girl's new Netflix documentary has landed - under the shadow of a reported family feud.

item.title: What is chickenpox and who can get an NHS vaccine?
item.description: The standard NHS childhood vaccination programme will include chickenpox from 2 January 2026.

item.title: The teenage caffeine pouch trend troubling US experts
item.description: Some social media influencers are pushing products to young gym-goers and students, health experts warn.

item.title: Sleep, exercise, hydrate - do we really need to stick to recommended daily doses?
item.description: As a study casts doubt on the daily steps maxim, we take a look at some other health benchmarks we’re often told to strive for.

item.title: Is the most expensive lip balm always the best?
item.description: Do you need to spend more to get the best for your chapped lips?

item.title: Ketamine helped me escape my negative thoughts - then it nearly killed me
item.description: Young people are taking dangerous amounts of ket because it's cheap, easily available and helps them "disconnect", experts say.

item.title: The English neighbourhood that claims to hold the secret to fixing the NHS
item.description: With public satisfaction in the NHS just 21%, one area has a plan to shake up its services that could reduce GP waiting lists, as well as unblock hospital beds - but can it really work nationwide?

item.title: How does the disposable vape ban work, and how harmful is vaping?
item.description: The disposable vape ban is designed to reduce environmental damage and protect children's health.

item.title: Labour's plan for benefits throws up a bigger dilemma
item.description: The debate has sparked a wider dilemma about the broader purpose of welfare

item.title: First place in British Isles set to approve right to die
item.description: Laws in the Isle of Man to let terminally ill adults end their own lives are in the last stages of debate.

item.title: Generation K: The disturbing rise of ketamine abuse among young people
item.description: Increasing numbers of young people are using the drug, experts say. The health impacts can be catastrophic.

item.title: Assisted dying bill: What is in proposed law?
item.description: The proposed law would allow some terminally ill adults to end their own lives. But there are requirements.

item.title: 'My first cervical screening was over before I knew it'
item.description: The BBC speaks to six people about their first cervical screening, and what they wish they'd known beforehand.

item.title: Is the system letting down people who were harmed by Covid vaccines?
item.description: People affected by rare blood clots say they feel they have been airbrushed out of the pandemic.

item.title: How will weight-loss drugs change our relationship with food?
item.description: The rise of these treatments has major implications for how we think about obesity, says James Gallagher.

item.title: NHS needs better plan around weight loss jabs, warn experts
item.description: Experts call for an urgent review of obesity treatment services amid booming demand for weight loss jabs.

item.title: How many of us will end up being diagnosed with ADHD?
item.description: Experts suggest that the number of people with ADHD is actually going to remain steady.

item.title: The junior doctors' strikes may be over. But is trouble ahead?
item.description: The end of the pay dispute sounded too good to be true. And now some are wondering if it might be.

item.title: Why are resident doctors striking and how much are they paid?
item.description: Resident doctors in England are striking between 17 and 22 December, the 14th walkout since 2023.

item.title: Union and government to restart talks on ending doctor dispute
item.description: BMA says there is window of opportunity in coming weeks to reach a settlement after 12 strikes.

item.title: Doctors' union agrees to resume talks with Streeting
item.description: But the health secretary says he will not negotiate on pay, adding that the union has lost goodwill with their five-day walkout.

item.title: The doctor strike has ended - what comes next?
item.description: With doctors returning to work after five-day walkout, is there an opportunity for talks to re-start?

item.title: The rugby mum looking to get others to play
item.description: Annette Bevan and friends set up the Maa Maas club for mums who want to play rugby.

item.title: 'My endometriosis pain is excruciating but I'm still waiting for surgery'
item.description: According to the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, 59,733 women in NI are now on waiting lists.

item.title: I stopped paying for food and heating to spend it gambling - my period made it worse
item.description: Researchers are looking to see if there is a link between hormonal fluctuations and gambling addiction.

item.title: Woman planning 115km walk after two heart attacks
item.description: Cathy Read will walk across Spain to support the charity that helped her recover.

item.title: Tackling the gender gap in CPR treatment
item.description: Research shows women are 27% less likely than men to receive CPR from bystanders.

item.title: NHS funds football pitch to help boost island health
item.description: Carloway Football Club in Lewis has received a grant of £22,000.

item.title: Libraries to host community events over winter
item.description: The sessions in December and January aim to bring people in Wolverhampton together during the colder months.

item.title: 'It sounds dramatic but singing class saved my life'
item.description: Hundreds of peopling attending singing groups are being taught songs and breathing techniques.

item.title: Wellbeing support for terminally-ill islanders
item.description: A hospice offers a free programme for those with life-limiting or serious progressive illnesses.

item.title: At 21, I was crushed by a stranger's joke about going bald. Then the way I looked at myself changed
item.description: There are multiple ways for men to combat hair loss now, but should they have to?

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: Should we be having regular saunas? Plus, a breakthrough result for Huntington’s disease.

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: Cystic fibrosis care, AI in cancer screening & science of run clubs.

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: Shingles vaccine to reduce dementia risk? Antibiotic resistant gonorrhoea & tech trousers

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: We investigate the safety of melatonin as a sleep aid, and should you eat your placenta?

item.title: Is Dry January a good thing?
item.description: Dr May van Schalkwyk from the University of Edinburgh shares her thoughts with Drs Chris and Xand on What's Up Docs?

item.title: How going on The Traitors could have saved Amanda's life
item.description: Medical checks for the show picked up contestant Amanda Collier's heart condition.

item.title: How to spot illicit cigarettes
item.description: Morning Live's Marc Cananur finds out more about the health risks around illegal cigarettes.

item.title: Are there 'forever chemicals' in your raincoat?
item.description: Could your skin be absorbing PFAS (Perfluoroalkyl and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances), also known as 'forever chemicals' through your raincoat?
